AC Code

# 991C - Candies

time limit per test: 1 second
memory limit per test: 256 megabytes
input: standard input
output: standard output

After passing a test, Vasya got himself a box of nnn candies. He decided to eat an equal amount of candies each morning until there are no more candies. However, Petya also noticed the box and decided to get some candies for himself.

This means the process of eating candies is the following: in the beginning Vasya chooses a single integer kkk, same for all days. After that, in the morning he eats kkk candies from the box (if there are less than kkk candies in the box, he eats them all), then in the evening Petya eats 10%10\%10% of the candies remaining in the box. If there are still candies left in the box, the process repeats â€” next day Vasya eats kkk candies again, and Petya â€” 10%10\%10% of the candies left in a box, and so on.

If the amount of candies in the box is not divisible by 101010, Petya rounds the amount he takes from the box down. For example, if there were 979797 candies in the box, Petya would eat only 999 of them. In particular, if there are less than 101010 candies in a box, Petya won't eat any at all.

Your task is to find out the minimal amount of kkk that can be chosen by Vasya so that he would eat at least half of the nnn candies he initially got. Note that the number kkk must be integer.

Input

The first line contains a single integer nnn (1â‰¤nâ‰¤10181 \leq n \leq 10^{18}1â‰¤nâ‰¤1018) â€” the initial amount of candies in the box.

Output

Output a single integer â€” the minimal amount of kkk that would allow Vasya to eat at least half of candies he got.

Example

Input
68
Output
3

Note

In the sample, the amount of candies, with k=3k=3k=3, would change in the following way (Vasya eats first):

68â†’65â†’59â†’56â†’51â†’48â†’44â†’41â†’37â†’34â†’31â†’28â†’26â†’23â†’21â†’18â†’17â†’14â†’13â†’10â†’9â†’6â†’6â†’3â†’3â†’068â†’65â†’59â†’56â†’51â†’48â†’44â†’41â†’37â†’34â†’31â†’28â†’26â†’23â†’21â†’18â†’17â†’14â†’13â†’10â†’9â†’6â†’6â†’3â†’3â†’0.

In total, Vasya would eat 393939 candies, while Petya â€” 292929.

AC Code

# 1714D - Color with Occurrences

You are given some text ttt and a set of nnn strings s1,s2,â€¦,sns_1, s_2, \dots, s_ns1â€‹,s2â€‹,â€¦,snâ€‹.

In one step, you can choose any occurrence of any string sis_isiâ€‹ in the text ttt and color the corresponding characters of the text in red. For example, if t=bababat=\texttt{bababa}t=bababa and s1=bas_1=\texttt{ba}s1â€‹=ba, s2=abas_2=\texttt{aba}s2â€‹=aba, you can get t=bababat=\color{red}{\texttt{ba}}\texttt{baba}t=bababa, t=bababat=\texttt{b}\color{red}{\texttt{aba}}\texttt{ba}t=bababa or t=bababat=\texttt{bab}\color{red}{\texttt{aba}}t=bababa in one step.

You want to color all the letters of the text ttt in red. When you color a letter in red again, it stays red.

In the example above, three steps are enough:

  • Let's color t[2â€¦4]=s2=abat[2 \dots 4]=s_2=\texttt{aba}t[2â€¦4]=s2â€‹=aba in red, we get t=bababat=\texttt{b}\color{red}{\texttt{aba}}\texttt{ba}t=bababa;
  • Let's color t[1â€¦2]=s1=bat[1 \dots 2]=s_1=\texttt{ba}t[1â€¦2]=s1â€‹=ba in red, we get t=bababat=\color{red}{\texttt{baba}}\texttt{ba}t=bababa;
  • Let's color t[4â€¦6]=s2=abat[4 \dots 6]=s_2=\texttt{aba}t[4â€¦6]=s2â€‹=aba in red, we get t=bababat=\color{red}{\texttt{bababa}}t=bababa.

Each string sis_isiâ€‹ can be applied any number of times (or not at all). Occurrences for coloring can intersect arbitrarily.

Determine the minimum number of steps needed to color all letters ttt in red and how to do it. If it is impossible to color all letters of the text ttt in red, output -1.

Input

The first line of the input contains an integer qqq (1â‰¤qâ‰¤1001 \le q \le 1001â‰¤qâ‰¤100) â€”the number of test cases in the test.

The descriptions of the test cases follow.

The first line of each test case contains the text ttt (1â‰¤âˆ£tâˆ£â‰¤1001 \le |t| \le 1001â‰¤âˆ£tâˆ£â‰¤100), consisting only of lowercase Latin letters, where âˆ£tâˆ£|t|âˆ£tâˆ£ is the length of the text ttt.

The second line of each test case contains a single integer nnn (1â‰¤nâ‰¤101 \le n \le 101â‰¤nâ‰¤10) â€” the number of strings in the set.

This is followed by nnn lines, each containing a string sis_isiâ€‹ (1â‰¤âˆ£siâˆ£â‰¤101 \le |s_i| \le 101â‰¤âˆ£siâ€‹âˆ£â‰¤10) consisting only of lowercase Latin letters, where âˆ£siâˆ£|s_i|âˆ£siâ€‹âˆ£ â€” the length of string sis_isiâ€‹.

Output

For each test case, print the answer on a separate line.

If it is impossible to color all the letters of the text in red, print a single line containing the number -1.

Otherwise, on the first line, print the number mmm â€” the minimum number of steps it will take to turn all the letters ttt red.

Then in the next mmm lines print pairs of indices: wjw_jwjâ€‹ and pjp_jpjâ€‹ (1â‰¤jâ‰¤m1 \le j \le m1â‰¤jâ‰¤m), which denote that the string with index wjw_jwjâ€‹ was used as a substring to cover the occurrences starting in the text ttt from position pjp_jpjâ€‹. The pairs can be output in any order.

If there are several answers, output any of them.

Example

Input
6
bababa
2
ba
aba
caba
2
bac
acab
abacabaca
3
aba
bac
aca
baca
3
a
c
b

def

efo
forces
aaaabbbbcccceeee
4

cccc

bbbb
Output
3
2 2
1 1
2 4
-1
4

3 7
4
3 1

2 3

2
4 5
2 1
4
3 1
4 5

1 13

Note

The first test case is explained in the problem statement.

In the second test case, it is impossible to color all the letters of the text in red.

# 938D - Buy a Ticket

Musicians of a popular band "Flayer" have announced that they are going to "make their exit" with a world tour. Of course, they will visit Berland as well.

There are n cities in Berland. People can travel between cities using two-directional train routes; there are exactly m routes, i-th route can be used to go from city viv_{i}viâ€‹ to city uiu_{i}uiâ€‹ (and from uiu_{i}uiâ€‹ to viv_{i}viâ€‹), and it costs wiw_{i}wiâ€‹ coins to use this route.

Each city will be visited by "Flayer", and the cost of the concert ticket in i-th city is aia_{i}aiâ€‹ coins.

You have friends in every city of Berland, and they, knowing about your programming skills, asked you to calculate the minimum possible number of coins they have to pay to visit the concert. For every city i you have to compute the minimum number of coins a person from city i has to spend to travel to some city j (or possibly stay in city i), attend a concert there, and return to city i (if jâ€‰â‰ â€‰i).

Formally, for everyiâˆˆ[1,n]i\in[1, n]iâˆˆ[1,n] you have to calculateminâ¡jâˆˆ[1,n]2d(i,j)+aj\min _{j\in[1,n]} 2 d(i, j)+a_{j}minjâˆˆ[1,n]â€‹2d(i,j)+ajâ€‹ , where d(i,â€‰j) is the minimum number of coins you have to spend to travel from city i to city j. If there is no way to reach city j from city i, then we consider d(i,â€‰j) to be infinitely large.

Input

The first line contains two integers n and m (2â€‰â‰¤â€‰nâ€‰â‰¤â€‰2â‹…105,1â€‰â‰¤â€‰mâ€‰â‰¤â€‰2â‹…1052â€‰â‰¤â€‰nâ€‰â‰¤â€‰2Â·10^{5}, 1â€‰â‰¤â€‰mâ€‰â‰¤â€‰2Â·10^{5}2â€‰â‰¤â€‰nâ€‰â‰¤â€‰2â‹…105,1â€‰â‰¤â€‰mâ€‰â‰¤â€‰2â‹…105).

Then m lines follow, i-th contains three integers viv_{i}viâ€‹, uiu_{i}uiâ€‹ and wiw_{i}wiâ€‹ (1â€‰â‰¤â€‰vi,â€‰uiâ‰¤â€‰n,â€‰viâ‰ â€‰ui,1â€‰â‰¤â€‰wiâ€‰â‰¤â€‰10121â€‰â‰¤â€‰v_{i},â€‰u_{i}â‰¤â€‰n,â€‰v_{i}â‰ â€‰u_{i}, 1â€‰â‰¤â€‰w_{i}â€‰â‰¤â€‰10^{12}1â€‰â‰¤â€‰viâ€‹,â€‰uiâ€‹â‰¤â€‰n,â€‰viâ€‹î€ =â€‰uiâ€‹,1â€‰â‰¤â€‰wiâ€‹â€‰â‰¤â€‰1012) denoting i-th train route. There are no multiple train routes connecting the same pair of cities, that is, for each (v,â€‰u) neither extra (v,â€‰u) nor (u,â€‰v) present in input.

The next line contains n integers a1,â€‰a2,â€‰...ak(1â€‰â‰¤â€‰aiâ€‰â‰¤â€‰1012)a_{1},â€‰a_2,â€‰... a_k (1â€‰â‰¤â€‰a_iâ€‰â‰¤â€‰10^{12})a1â€‹,â€‰a2â€‹,â€‰...akâ€‹(1â€‰â‰¤â€‰aiâ€‹â€‰â‰¤â€‰1012) â€” price to attend the concert in i-th city.

Output

Print n integers. i-th of them must be equal to the minimum number of coins a person from city i has to spend to travel to some city j (or possibly stay in city i), attend a concert there, and return to city i (if jâ€‰â‰ â€‰i).

Example

Input
4 2
1 2 4
2 3 7
6 20 1 25
Output
6 14 1 25

Input
3 3
1 2 1
2 3 1
1 3 1
30 10 20
Output
12 10 12
